questions: An elderly gentleman presents with a three day history of bloody diarrhoea and feverishness. He has no significant travel history. His past medical history is listed as hypertension, osteoarthritis and gout. On examination his temperature is 38.0ºC, heart rate 95/min, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. A stool sample has grown Salmonella. What is the best treatment?
notes: The BNF recommends treating invasive diarrhoea (causing bloody diarrhoea and fever) with ciprofloxacin. Most viral or bacterial gastroenteritis do not require treatment. The BNF recommends antibiotics for bacterial gastroenteritis in severe infections or in immunocompromised patients. Clarithromycin is used for traveller's diarrhoea and non-invasive diarrhoeal illnesses when treatment is necessary.
question: An elderly gentleman presents with a three day history of bloody diarrhoea and feverishness. He has no significant travel history. His past medical history is listed as hypertension, osteoarthritis and gout. On examination his temperature is 38.0ºC, heart rate 95/min, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. A stool sample has grown Salmonella. What is the best treatment?
question_notes: The BNF recommends treating invasive diarrhoea (causing bloody diarrhoea and fever) with ciprofloxacin. Most viral or bacterial gastroenteritis do not require treatment. The BNF recommends antibiotics for bacterial gastroenteritis in severe infections or in immunocompromised patients. Clarithromycin is used for traveller's diarrhoea and non-invasive diarrhoeal illnesses when treatment is necessary.
title: Enteric fever (typhoid/paratyphoid)
body:
The Salmonella group contains many members, most of which cause diarrhoeal diseases. They are aerobic, Gram-negative rods which are not normally present as commensals in the gut.

Typhoid and paratyphoid are caused by Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi (types A, B & C) respectively. They are often termed enteric fevers, producing systemic symptoms such as headache, fever, arthralgia.

Pathophysiology
  • typhoid is transmitted via the faecal-oral route (also in contaminated food and water)

Features
  • initially systemic upset as above
  • relative bradycardia
  • abdominal pain, distension
  • constipation: although Salmonella is a recognised cause of diarrhoea, constipation is more common in typhoid
  • rose spots: present on the trunk in 40% of patients, and are more common in paratyphoid

Possible complications include
  • osteomyelitis (especially in sickle cell disease where Salmonella is one of the most common pathogens)
  • GI bleed/perforation
  • meningitis
  • cholecystitis
  • chronic carriage (1%, more likely if adult females)
links:
DermNet NZ710
Typhoid fever review
media:
Salmonella - a quick introduction and overview
Let's Learn About Bugs - YouTube60
 
Salmonella
SketchyMedical - YouTube151
 
Salmonella
ATP - YouTube11

1650.concept_text: Salmonella typhi infection can cause rose spots on the abdomen

9520.concept_text: Although salmonella is a recognised cause of diarrhoea, constipation is more common in typhoid

questions:
A 55-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for a routine review. On examination, he appears well and there are no abnormal examination findings except for his blood pressure, which is recorded at 160/110 mmHg. Routine blood tests are performed which demonstrate the following:

Na+139 mmol/L(135 - 145)
K+4.5 mmol/L(3.5 - 5.0)
Urea16 mmol/L(2.0 - 7.0)
Creatinine163 µmol/L(55 - 120)

What additional feature would suggest that the cause of this presentation is chronic and not acute?
notes:
Hypocalcaemia is correct. This patient has blood tests suggestive of renal impairment, as shown by the increased urea and creatinine, which may be due to his history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (which can cause diabetic nephropathy). It is important to establish whether the renal impairment is acute or chronic, as their management varies significantly. Chronic renal failure can lead to impaired conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, which is needed for intestinal calcium absorption. This makes hypocalcaemia a marker that suggests the kidney disease is chronic and not acute, as an acute kidney injury is not associated with hypocalcaemia.

Anuria is incorrect. Most patients with chronic kidney disease are asymptomatic until very late-stage renal disease occurs and at this point, they would manifest other symptoms alongside such as oedema, anaemia, pruritus etc. The presence of oliguria is more suggestive of an acute kidney injury in this scenario as it is unlikely for him to have progressed this far with his chronic kidney disease in the absence of other symptoms.

Haematuria is incorrect. Most patients with chronic kidney disease are asymptomatic until very late-stage renal disease occurs. The presence of anuria is more suggestive of an acute kidney injury.

Normal parathyroid hormone levels is incorrect. Chronic kidney disease is a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to the impaired conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, which is needed for intestinal calcium absorption. This leads to hypocalcaemia, which in turn leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Oliguria is incorrect. Most patients with chronic kidney disease are asymptomatic until very late-stage renal disease occurs and at this point, they would manifest other symptoms alongside such as oedema, anaemia, pruritus etc. The presence of oliguria is more suggestive of an acute kidney injury in this scenario as it is unlikely for him to have progressed this far with his chronic kidney disease in the absence of other symptoms.

title: Acute kidney injury vs. chronic kidney disease
body:
One of the best ways to differentiate between acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) is renal ultrasound - most patients with CKD have bilateral small kidneys. Exceptions to this rule include:
  • autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • diabetic nephropathy (early stages)
  • amyloidosis
  • HIV-associated nephropathy

Other features suggesting CKD rather than AKI
  • hypocalcaemia (due to lack of vitamin D)
concept: Hypocalcaemia is an indication that kidney disease is chronic and not acute

4173.concept_text: Hypocalcaemia is an indication that kidney disease is chronic and not acute

questions:
A 29-year-old medical student presents to his general practitioner with earache. He believes this is associated with the same condition causing dryness in his scalp and beard and the eczema-like patches in his nasolabial folds. He has been managing these symptoms with over the counter topical remedies but would like some advice for his otalgia.

What is the likely diagnosis, out of those listed, which unifies this patient's symptoms?
notes:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of eczema-like plaques and dry skin in sebum rich areas of skin (likely seborrhoeic dermatitis) which he has been managing himself with over-the-counter antifungal shampoos. His complaint of earache may be due to otitis externa, a condition associated with seborrhoeic dermatitis however a full ear examination should be performed and other diagnoses excluded.

Contact dermatitis is a cause of dry skin (on areas such as the scalp) but it is unlikely to present in this distribution. It would not cause otalgia.

Eczema herpeticum is a severe primary infection by herpes-simplex-virus 1 or 2, commonly seen in children with atopic eczema. Presentation with rapidly progressing painful rash (monomorphic punched out lesions 1-3mm in diameter), lymphadenopathy and fever.

Guttate psoriasis commonly affects children after Streptococcal upper respiratory tract infection and will clear over the course of ~3 months without treatment. Presentation is with widespread, rain-drop like lesions across the trunk.

Irritant dermatitis is unlikely to cause such focal areas of irritation.
question:
A 29-year-old medical student presents to his general practitioner with earache. He believes this is associated with the same condition causing dryness in his scalp and beard and the eczema-like patches in his nasolabial folds. He has been managing these symptoms with over the counter topical remedies but would like some advice for his otalgia.

What is the likely diagnosis, out of those listed, which unifies this patient's symptoms?
question_notes:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of eczema-like plaques and dry skin in sebum rich areas of skin (likely seborrhoeic dermatitis) which he has been managing himself with over-the-counter antifungal shampoos. His complaint of earache may be due to otitis externa, a condition associated with seborrhoeic dermatitis however a full ear examination should be performed and other diagnoses excluded.

title: Seborrhoeic dermatitis in adults
body:
Seborrhoeic dermatitis in adults is a chronic dermatitis thought to be caused by an inflammatory reaction related to a proliferation of a normal skin inhabitant, a fungus called Malassezia furfur (formerly known as Pityrosporum ovale). It is common, affecting around 2% of the general population.

Features
  • eczematous lesions on the sebum-rich areas: scalp (may cause dandruff), periorbital, auricular and nasolabial folds
  • otitis externa and blepharitis may develop


Associated conditions include
  • HIV
  • Parkinson's disease

Scalp disease management
  • the first-line treatment is ketoconazole 2% shampoo
  • over the counter preparations containing zinc pyrithione ('Head & Shoulders') and tar ('Neutrogena T/Gel') may be used if ketoconazole is not appropriate or acceptable to the person
  • selenium sulphide and topical corticosteroid may also be useful

Face and body management
  • topical antifungals: e.g. ketoconazole
  • topical steroids: best used for short periods
  • difficult to treat - recurrences are common
concept: Otitis externa and blepharitis are common complications of seborrhoeic dermatitis
links:
DermNet NZ216
Overview and pictures of seborrhoeic dermatitis

340.concept_text: Seborrhoeic dermatitis - first-line treatment is topical ketoconazole

8750.concept_text: An itchy rash affecting the face and scalp distribution is commonly caused by seborrhoeic dermatitis

8942.concept_text: Otitis externa and blepharitis are common complications of seborrhoeic dermatitis

8944.concept_text: Parkinson's disease is associated with seborrhoeic dermatitis

theme: First-line pharmacological treatment for newly diagnosed COPD
questions:
A 72-year-old retired coal miner presents to the respiratory clinic with worsening dyspnoea over 6 months. He has a 50 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He uses no inhalers currently. His MRC dyspnoea score is 3. Examination reveals a barrel-shaped chest with decreased breath sounds and prolonged expiration. His recent spirometry results are below:

FEV11.8 L (62% predicted)(>80% predicted)
FVC3.2 L (85% predicted)(>80% predicted)
FEV1/FVC ratio0.56(>0.7)
PEFR320 L/min(>400 L/min)

Which pharmacological treatment would be most appropriate to initiate?
notes:
Salbutamol inhaler as required is the correct answer according to NICE guidelines for COPD management. This patient presents with typical features of COPD including significant smoking history, barrel-shaped chest, and spirometry confirming airflow obstruction (FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7). His FEV1 is 62% predicted, classifying his COPD as moderate severity. According to the NICE COPD guidelines, a short-acting beta-2 agonist (SABA) such as salbutamol or a short-acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA) should be the first-line pharmacological treatment for COPD. This is recommended as initial therapy regardless of disease severity to provide symptom relief as needed. The patient has not previously been on any inhaler therapy, so starting with a SABA follows the appropriate stepwise approach to COPD management. Only if the patient remains symptomatic despite using short-acting bronchodilators should therapy be escalated.

Tiotropium inhaler once daily is incorrect as first-line therapy. While long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMAs) like tiotropium are effective bronchodilators in COPD, they are typically recommended as step-up therapy when patients remain symptomatic despite using short-acting bronchodilators. Starting with a LAMA before trying a SABA would skip a step in the recommended treatment pathway and would not align with cost-effective prescribing principles.

Salmeterol inhaler twice daily is incorrect as initial therapy. Long-acting beta-2 agonists (LABAs) like salmeterol are recommended as step-up therapy in COPD, typically after short-acting bronchodilators have been tried. According to NICE guidelines, a LABA would be considered in combination with a LAMA for patients without asthmatic features who remain symptomatic on short-acting bronchodilators, not as first-line monotherapy.

Beclometasone inhaler twice daily is incorrect. Inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) monotherapy is not recommended at any stage in the management of COPD according to NICE guidelines. ICS therapy should only be considered in combination with a LABA for patients who have asthmatic features or features suggesting steroid responsiveness, and even then, not as first-line therapy.

Salmeterol/fluticasone combination inhaler twice daily is incorrect as initial therapy. LABA/ICS combinations are recommended only for patients with asthmatic features or features suggesting steroid responsiveness who remain symptomatic despite short-acting bronchodilators. This patient has no documented features suggesting steroid responsiveness (such as blood eosinophilia, previous asthma diagnosis, or significant FEV1 variability). Starting with this combination would be inappropriate as first-line therapy and could expose the patient to unnecessary side effects from the inhaled corticosteroid component.

Starting with this combination would be inappropriate as first-line therapy and could expose the patient to unnecessary side effects from the inhaled corticosteroid component.
title: COPD: stable management
body:
NICE updated its guidelines on the management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in 2018.

General management
  • >smoking cessation advice: including offering nicotine replacement therapy, varenicline or bupropion
  • annual influenza vaccination
  • one-off pneumococcal vaccination
  • pulmonary rehabilitation to all people who view themselves as functionally disabled by COPD (usually Medical Research Council [MRC] grade 3 and above)

Bronchodilator therapy
  • a short-acting beta2-agonist (SABA) or short-acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA) is first-line treatment
  • for patients who remain breathless or have exacerbations despite using short-acting bronchodilators the next step is determined by whether the patient has 'asthmatic features/features suggesting steroid responsiveness'

There are a number of criteria NICE suggest to determine whether a patient has asthmatic/steroid responsive features:
  • any previous, secure diagnosis of asthma or of atopy
  • a higher blood eosinophil count - note that NICE recommend a full blood count for all patients as part of the work-up
  • substantial variation in FEV1 over time (at least 400 ml)
  • substantial diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (at least 20%)

Interestingly NICE do not recommend formal reversibility testing as one of the criteria. In the guidelines they state that 'routine spirometric reversibility testing is not necessary as part of the diagnostic process or to plan initial therapy with bronchodilators or corticosteroids. It may be unhelpful or misleading...'. They then go on to discuss why they have reached this conclusion. Please see the guidelines for more details.

No asthmatic features/features suggesting steroid responsiveness
  • add a long-acting beta2-agonist (LABA) + long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA)
    • if already taking a SAMA, discontinue and switch to a SABA

Asthmatic features/features suggesting steroid responsiveness
  • LABA + inhaled corticosteroid (ICS)
  • if patients remain breathless or have exacerbations offer triple therapy i.e. LAMA + LABA + ICS
    • if already taking a SAMA, discontinue and switch to a SABA
  • NICE recommend the use of combined inhalers where possible
  • NICE specifically mention the risk of pneumonia in patients with COPD using inhaled corticosteroids


Oral theophylline
  • NICE only recommends theophylline after trials of short and long-acting bronchodilators or to people who cannot used inhaled therapy
  • the dose should be reduced if macrolide or fluoroquinolone antibiotics are co-prescribed

Oral prophylactic antibiotic therapy
  • azithromycin prophylaxis is recommended in select patients
  • patients should not smoke, have optimised standard treatments and continue to have exacerbations
  • other prerequisites include a CT thorax (to exclude bronchiectasis) and sputum culture (to exclude atypical infections and tuberculosis)
  • LFTs and an ECG to exclude QT prolongation should also be done as azithromycin can prolong the QT interval

Standby medication: NICE recommend offering a short course of oral corticosteroids and oral antibiotics to keep at home if: NICE
  • have had an exacerbation within the last year
  • understand how to take the medication, and are aware of associated risks and benefits
  • know to when to seek help and when to ask for replacements once medication has been used

Mucolytics
  • should be 'considered' in patients with a chronic productive cough and continued if symptoms improve

Phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitors NICE
  • oral PDE-4 inhibitors such as roflumilast reduce the risk of COPD exacerbations in patients with severe COPD and a history of frequent COPD exacerbations
  • NICE recommend if:
    • the disease is severe, defined as a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) after a bronchodilator of less than 50% of predicted normal, and
    • the person has had 2 or more exacerbations in the previous 12 months despite triple inhaled therapy with a long-acting muscarinic antagonist, a long-acting beta-2 agonist and an inhaled corticosteroid

Cor pulmonale
  • features include peripheral oedema, raised jugular venous pressure, systolic parasternal heave, loud P2
  • use a loop diuretic for oedema, consider long-term oxygen therapy
  • ACE-inhibitors, calcium channel blockers and alpha blockers are not recommended by NICE

Factors which may improve survival in patients with stable COPD
  • smoking cessation - the single most important intervention in patients who are still smoking
  • long term oxygen therapy in patients who fit criteria
  • lung volume reduction surgery in selected patients
concept: A SABA or SAMA is the first-line pharmacological treatment of COPD
links:
Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease2539
GOLD criteria 2017


NICE1921
Roflumilast NICE recommendations


NICE3533
2018 COPD guidelines


NICE5016
2018 COPD management diagram
media:
Chronic bronchitis
Osmosis - YouTube31
 
Cor pulmonale
Zero To Finals - YouTube83
 
Cor pulmonale
Osmosis - YouTube73
 
Understanding COPD
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube24

889.concept_text: COPD - still breathless despite using SABA/SAMA and no asthma/steroid responsive features --> add a LABA + LAMA

890.concept_text: COPD - still breathless despite using SABA/SAMA and asthma/steroid responsive features --> add a LABA + ICS

1499.concept_text: A SABA or SAMA is the first-line pharmacological treatment of COPD

7505.concept_text: COPD - still breathless despite using SABA/SAMA and a LABA + ICS --> add a LAMA

9525.concept_text:
Asthmatic features/features suggesting steroid responsiveness in COPD: 
   - previous diagnosis of asthma or atopy
   - a higher blood eosinophil count
   - substantial variation in FEV1 over time (at least 400 ml)
   - substantial diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (at least 20%)

9761.concept_text: Azithromycin prophylaxis is recommended in COPD patients who meet certain criteria and who continue to have exacerbations

12253.concept_text: COPD standby medication: NICE recommend offering a short course of oral corticosteroids and oral antibiotics to keep at home

questions:
A 68-year-old man presents with central chest pain and nausea. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. He is haemodynamically stable.

Select the single most likely coronary artery affected from the options below.
notes:
The correct answer is Right coronary artery. The ECG findings of ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF are characteristic of an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) affecting the inferior wall of the left ventricle. In approximately 85% of the population (a 'right-dominant' circulation), the inferior wall is supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is a terminal branch of the right coronary artery (RCA). Therefore, occlusion of the RCA is the most common cause of an inferior STEMI. The clinical presentation with nausea is also highly suggestive of an inferior MI, as vagal nerve stimulation from ischaemia of the inferior myocardium is common. The RCA also supplies the sinoatrial (SA) node (in ~60% of people) and the atrioventricular (AV) node (in ~90% of people). Consequently, patients with an RCA occlusion can present with bradycardia, sinus arrest, or varying degrees of AV block, which is an important clinical association to recognise. While the patient is currently haemodynamically stable, close monitoring for these complications is essential.

Left anterior descending artery occlusion is incorrect. The left anterior descending (LAD) artery primarily supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle and the interventricular septum. An occlusion of the LAD would typically manifest as ST-segment elevation in the anterior and septal leads on a 12-lead ECG. This would include leads V1-V4 for an anteroseptal infarct, or more extensively V1-V6, I, and aVL for a large anterior infarct. The ECG findings in this scenario (ST elevation in II, III, aVF) do not correspond to the LAD territory, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Left circumflex artery occlusion is incorrect. The left circumflex (LCx) artery supplies the lateral wall of the left ventricle. Occlusion of the LCx typically causes ST-segment elevation in the lateral leads: I, aVL, V5, and V6. In some cases, an LCx occlusion can cause a 'silent' posterior MI, which may present with reciprocal ST depression in leads V1-V3. A posterior ECG (with leads V7-V9) would be required to confirm ST elevation. In a minority of individuals with a 'left-dominant' circulation (~10%), the LCx gives rise to the PDA, and its occlusion could cause an inferior STEMI. However, this is far less common than an RCA occlusion, making the RCA the most likely affected vessel.

Left main stem artery occlusion is incorrect. The left main stem (LMS) artery bifurcates into the LAD and LCx arteries, supplying the majority of the left ventricle. A significant LMS occlusion is a life-threatening emergency, often referred to as a 'widow-maker' lesion. It typically results in widespread ST depression across multiple leads with concomitant ST elevation in lead aVR. Patients with a critical LMS occlusion are usually profoundly unwell and in cardiogenic shock. The patient in this scenario is described as haemodynamically stable with localised inferior ECG changes, making an LMS occlusion highly improbable.

Posterior descending artery is an incorrect option, although it is a plausible distractor. The posterior descending artery (PDA) does indeed supply the inferior wall of the heart, and its occlusion is the direct cause of the infarction. However, the PDA is a branch vessel, not one of the primary coronary arteries. In the majority of people (right-dominant circulation), the PDA arises from the right coronary artery. Therefore, the underlying pathology is an occlusion of the RCA proximal to the origin of the PDA. The question asks for the most likely coronary artery affected, and the RCA is the main vessel that has been occluded.

The posterior descending artery (PDA) does indeed supply the inferior wall of the heart, and its occlusion is the direct cause of the infarction. However, the PDA is a branch vessel, not one of the primary coronary arteries. In the majority of people (right-dominant circulation), the PDA arises from the right coronary artery. Therefore, the underlying pathology is an occlusion of the RCA proximal to the origin of the PDA. The question asks for the most likely coronary artery affected, and the RCA is the main vessel that has been occluded.
title: ECG: coronary territories
body:
The table below shows the correlation between ECG changes and coronary territories:

ECG changesCoronary artery
AnteroseptalV1-V4Left anterior descending
InferiorII, III, aVFRight coronary
AnterolateralV1-6, I, aVLProximal left anterior descending
LateralI, aVL +/- V5-6Left circumflex
PosteriorChanges in V1-3

Reciprocal changes of STEMI are typically seen:
  • horizontal ST depression
  • tall, broad R waves
  • upright T waves
  • dominant R wave in V2

Posterior infarction is confirmed by ST elevation and Q waves in posterior leads (V7-9)		Usually left circumflex, also right coronary

It should be remembered that a new left bundle branch block (LBBB) may point towards a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome.

Diagram showing the correlation between ECG changes and coronary territories in acute coronary syndrome
concept: Ischaemic changes in leads II, III, aVF - right coronary
links:
University of Massachusetts Medical School1936
Classic circumflex infarction ECG


Postgraduate Medical Journal3148
ECG correlation with coronary anatomy

915.concept_text: Inferior MI - right coronary artery lesion

8257.concept_text: Ischaemic changes in leads V1-V4 - left anterior descending

8258.concept_text: Ischaemic changes in leads II, III, aVF - right coronary

8259.concept_text: Ischaemic changes in leads I, aVL +/- V5-6 - left circumflex

11554.concept_text: Posterior infarction is confirmed by ST elevation and Q waves in posterior leads (V7-9)

questions:
A 33-year-old man presents to the optician with left vision loss. He noted central blurring and reduced colour vision 48 hours ago. This has now progressed to total vision loss. He also has pain behind the left eye that worsens with eye movements. Vision is unchanged in his right eye.

The patient has no ophthalmic history. He has a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis that is managed with ibuprofen.

On examination, he has 20/20 vision in his right eye and 20/6 vision in his left eye. There is a left relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy is unremarkable.

What is the likely diagnosis?
notes:
Optic neuritis presents with subacute unilateral vision loss and retro-orbital pain that is worse on eye movements. Colour desaturation is also common. A relative afferent pupillary defect is a common examination finding. Although not seen in this patient, there may also be optic disc swelling if the distal optic nerve is affected. However, often fundoscopy will be normal.

Whilst anterior uveitis is an important differential in this patient given his ankylosing spondylitis, it is not the diagnosis here. Anterior uveitis causes a red, painful eye with blurred vision, photophobia, and watering of the eye. A red eye with an unreactive or distorted pupil would be evident on examination.

Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy is a maternally inherited mitochondrial condition that can present similarly to optic neuritis, although vision loss typically becomes bilateral. It most commonly presents in young males like this patient and also causes subacute vision loss with colour desaturation. However, pain is rarely a feature of Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy. Optic disc oedema is seen on fundoscopy.

Scleritis is another cause of eye pain worsened by eye movements. However, patients with scleritis will have characteristic examination findings, including redness (which may be generalised or localised), a blue hue to the eyeball, and scleral oedema. Whilst scleritis can lead to vision loss without treatment, vision changes are not the presenting symptom.

Temporal arteritis would be uncommon in a patient this young. Vision loss in temporal arteritis is not accompanied by eye pain. A patient with temporal arteritis would have other features such as headache, jaw claudication, and constitutional symptoms.

title: Optic neuritis
body:
Causes
  • multiple sclerosis: the commonest associated disease
  • diabetes
  • syphilis

Features
  • unilateral decrease in visual acuity over hours or days
  • poor discrimination of colours, 'red desaturation'
  • pain worse on eye movement
  • relative afferent pupillary defect
  • central scotoma

Investigation
  • MRI of the brain and orbits with gadolinium contrast is diagnostic in most cases

Management
  • high-dose steroids
  • recovery usually takes 4-6 weeks

Prognosis
  • MRI: if > 3 white-matter lesions, 5-year risk of developing multiple sclerosis is c. 50%
concept: Subacute unilateral visual loss, eye pain worse on movements → ?optic neuritis

1298.concept_text: Subacute unilateral visual loss, eye pain worse on movements --> ?optic neuritis

3051.concept_text: Optic neuritis is associated with relative afferent pupillary defect

3251.concept_text: Colour vision ('red desaturation') is affected in optic neuritis

9128.concept_text: A central scotoma is a feature of optic neuritis

11248.concept_text: Multiple sclerosis is the most common cause of optic neuritis

11902.concept_text: Suspected optic neuritis: MRI of the brain and orbits with gadolinium contrast is the investigation of choice

options: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
questions:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a productive cough and shortness of breath. On further investigation, he reports ongoing lethargy and unintentional weight loss over the past four months. He has a 30-pack-year history.

Bloods show:

Na+124 mmol/L(135 - 145)
K+4.5 mmol/L(3.5 - 5.0)
Creatinine108 µmol/L(55 - 120)

A chest x-ray shows a mass in the right upper lobe with a small consolidation in the right middle zone.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Small-cell lung cancer is correct. Small-cell lung cancer is strongly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, particularly the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which explains the hyponatraemia seen in this patient. The combination of a significant smoking history, weight loss, respiratory symptoms, and chest X-ray findings strongly supports this diagnosis.

Adenocarcinoma of the lung is incorrect. Adenocarcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer which is the most common lung cancer in non-smokers and can cause respiratory symptoms; it is less commonly associated with significant hyponatraemia or SIADH compared to small-cell lung cancer. The specific patient history (including his significant smoking history) and symptoms presented are more indicative of small-cell lung cancer.

Carcinoid tumour of the lung is incorrect. Carcinoid tumours of the lung are rare, slow-growing neuroendocrine tumours that can cause carcinoid syndrome in some cases. Carcinoid syndrome is characterised by flushing, diarrhoea, and bronchospasm due to the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances. However, this patient’s presentation, particularly the severe hyponatraemia, is more consistent with SIADH rather than carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid tumours typically do not present with unintentional weight loss and profound lethargy like in this case.

Large-cell carcinoma of the lung is incorrect. Large cell carcinoma can present with similar symptoms, but it is not commonly associated with hyponatraemia. The typical presentation of this cancer does not align with the significant features of this case, especially the laboratory findings.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma typically leads to hypercalcaemia due to parathyroid hormone-related peptide secretion rather than hyponatraemia. The clinical scenario presented, including the patient’s smoking history and laboratory results, does not align with this diagnosis.
question:

Bloods show:

Na+124 mmol/L(135 - 145)
K+4.5 mmol/L(3.5 - 5.0)
Creatinine108 µmol/L(55 - 120)

A chest x-ray shows a mass in the right upper lobe with a small consolidation in the right middle zone.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
question_notes:
Small-cell lung cancer is correct. Small-cell lung cancer is strongly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, particularly the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which explains the hyponatraemia seen in this patient. The combination of a significant smoking history, weight loss, respiratory symptoms, and chest X-ray findings strongly supports this diagnosis.

The specific patient history (including his significant smoking history) and symptoms presented are more indicative of small-cell lung cancer.

Carcinoid syndrome is characterised by flushing, diarrhoea, and bronchospasm due to the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances. However, this patient’s presentation, particularly the severe hyponatraemia, is more consistent with SIADH rather than carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid tumours typically do not present with unintentional weight loss and profound lethargy like in this case.

Large-cell carcinoma of the lung is incorrect. Large cell carcinoma can present with similar symptoms, but it is not commonly associated with hyponatraemia. The typical presentation of this cancer does not align with the significant features of this case, especially the laboratory findings.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma typically leads to hypercalcaemia due to parathyroid hormone-related peptide secretion rather than hyponatraemia. The clinical scenario presented, including the patient’s smoking history and laboratory results, does not align with this diagnosis.
title: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion
body:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is characterised by hyponatraemia secondary to the dilutional effects of excessive water retention. Patients with SIADH are typically euvolemic, i.e. they do not show signs of overt volume depletion or overload.

Pathophysiology
  • SIADH involves an excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, which leads to water retention, volume expansion, and dilutional hyponatraemia
  • ADH is produced by the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary gland. Its primary function is to regulate the body's water balance
  • It does this by increasing water reabsorption in the collecting ducts of the kidneys, thereby decreasing the volume of urine produced
  • In SIADH, there is an inappropriate and continuous release of ADH that is not inhibited by normal physiological mechanisms, such as adequate or excess body fluid levels
  • As a result, the kidneys reabsorb more water, leading to decreased urine output, and expansion of extracellular fluid volume.
  • Importantly, this increase in body fluid volume does not lead to the expected signs of fluid overload, such as oedema or hypertension, because the excess fluid is uniformly distributed throughout all body fluid compartments.
  • However, as water is retained in the body, the concentration of electrolytes in the blood, particularly sodium, becomes diluted, leading to hyponatraemia.

Causes of SIADH

CategoryExamples
Malignancy
  • small cell lung cancer
  • also: pancreas, prostate
Neurological
  • stroke
  • subarachnoid haemorrhage
  • subdural haemorrhage
  • meningitis/encephalitis/abscess
Infections
  • tuberculosis
  • pneumonia
Drugs
  • sulfonylureas*
  • SSRIs, tricyclics
  • carbamazepine
  • vincristine
  • cyclophosphamide
Other causes
  • positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
  • porphyrias

Investigations
  • Urine osmolality: Urine osmolality is inappropriately high (>100 mOsm/kg) in relation to serum osmolality, as the kidneys should normally dilute urine in the setting of low serum osmolality.
  • Urine sodium concentration: Urine sodium concentration is typically high (>40 mmol/L) due to the action of ADH on the renal tubules.

Management
  • correction must be done slowly to avoid precipitating central pontine myelinolysis
  • fluid restriction
  • demeclocycline: reduces the responsiveness of the collecting tubule cells to ADH
  • ADH (vasopressin) receptor antagonists have been developed

*the BNF states this has been reported with glimepiride and glipizide.
concept: A common endocrine complication of small cell lung cancer is SIADH
media:
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)
Osmosis - YouTube61

808.concept_text: SIADH - drug causes: carbamazepine, sulfonylureas, SSRIs, tricyclics

9299.concept_text: A common endocrine complication of small cell lung cancer is SIADH

questions:
You are examining the back of a 74-year-old man and notice the following:

© Image used on license from DermNet NZ

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
The correct answer is Seborrhoeic keratoses. This man has multiple seborrhoeic keratoses, also known as basal cell papillomas.

Seborrhoeic keratoses are benign skin lesions that commonly occur in older individuals. They present as well-defined, waxy, 'stuck-on' papules or plaques with a variable colour ranging from light tan to dark brown. The surface of these lesions can be smooth or rough and may show keratotic plugs. They can appear anywhere on the body except the palms and soles.

Bowen's disease, also known as squamous cell carcinoma in situ, is incorrect because this condition typically presents as a single, slow-growing, erythematous, scaly patch or plaque with well-defined borders. It doesn't usually appear as multiple lesions like the ones shown in the image.

Multiple benign moles is not the correct answer either. While older individuals may have multiple moles (nevi), they generally do not have the 'stuck-on' appearance seen in seborrhoeic keratoses. Moles are typically flat or raised pigmented lesions that are uniform in colour.

The diagnosis of Metastatic malignant melanoma is unlikely based on the image. Metastatic melanoma would suggest widespread disease and would likely present with other systemic symptoms such as weight loss or lymphadenopathy. Cutaneous metastases from melanoma often appear as rapidly growing pigmented nodules which are not evident here.

Finally, Dysplastic naevus syndrome, also known as familial atypical multiple mole-melanoma (FAMMM) syndrome, is characterised by numerous (>50) atypical moles that vary in size and colour and have irregular borders. People with this syndrome have a high risk of developing malignant melanoma. However, the lesions seen here do not exhibit features typical of dysplastic nevi such as variation in pigmentation and irregular borders.

People with this syndrome have a high risk of developing malignant melanoma. However, the lesions seen here do not exhibit features typical of dysplastic nevi such as variation in pigmentation and irregular borders.
title: Seborrhoeic keratoses
body:
Seborrhoeic keratoses are benign epidermal skin lesions seen in older people.

Features
  • large variation in colour from flesh to light-brown to black
  • have a 'stuck-on' appearance
  • keratotic plugs may be seen on the surface

The sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratoses may indicate an underlying malignancy, known as the Leser–Trélat sign. It is thought to result from tumour-derived growth factors, such as epidermal growth factor and transforming growth factor-α, stimulating keratinocyte proliferation.


Management
  • reassurance about the benign nature of the lesion is an option
  • options for removal include curettage, cryosurgery and shave biopsy
links:
DermNet NZ97
Seborrhoeic keratoses

questions:
A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of 'dizziness'. These attacks typically last around 30-60 minutes and occur every few days or so. During an attack 'the room seems to be spinning' and the patient often feels sick. These episodes are often accompanied by a 'roaring' sensation in the left ear. Otoscopy is normal, Weber's test localises to the right ear, and Rinne's test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
The correct answer is Meniere's disease. This condition is characterised by episodic vertigo, tinnitus (often described as a 'roaring' sensation), and sensorineural hearing loss. The symptoms typically last from 20 minutes to several hours. Meniere's disease is thought to be caused by an excess of endolymph in the inner ear, although the exact cause remains unknown. The presentation of this patient with recurrent episodes of vertigo accompanied by tinnitus localising to one ear makes Meniere's disease the most likely diagnosis.

Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, usually presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus and imbalance rather than true vertigo. It is a slow-growing benign tumour of the eighth cranial nerve. However, it would not typically cause episodic symptoms as described in the question.

Vestibular neuritis is typically characterised by a single episode of severe vertigo lasting days rather than recurrent episodes. It often follows a viral infection and may be associated with nausea and vomiting but does not typically cause tinnitus or hearing loss.

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) causes brief episodes of mild to intense dizziness that are triggered by specific changes in the position of your head. Episodes are often less than one minute and occur when moving in certain directions or at certain times, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. BPPV would not explain the 'roaring' sensation in her ear.

Multiple sclerosis can certainly present with vertigo but would usually have other neurological symptoms too such as visual disturbances or limb weakness which are not mentioned here. Multiple sclerosis also tends to present with more persistent symptoms rather than episodic ones.
question:

title: Meniere's disease
body:
Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear of unknown cause. It is characterised by excessive pressure and progressive dilation of the endolymphatic system. It is more common in middle-aged adults but may be seen at any age. Meniere's disease has a similar prevalence in both men and women.

Features
  • recurrent episodes of vertigo, tinnitus and hearing loss (sensorineural). Vertigo is usually the prominent symptom
  • a sensation of aural fullness or pressure is now recognised as being common
  • other features include nystagmus and a positive Romberg test
  • episodes last minutes to hours
  • typically symptoms are unilateral but bilateral symptoms may develop after a number of years

Natural history
  • symptoms resolve in the majority of patients after 5-10 years
  • the majority of patients will be left with a degree of hearing loss
  • psychological distress is common

Management
  • ENT assessment is required to confirm the diagnosis
  • patients should inform the DVLA. The current advice is to cease driving until satisfactory control of symptoms is achieved
  • acute attacks: buccal or intramuscular prochlorperazine. Admission is sometimes required
  • prevention: betahistine and vestibular rehabilitation exercises may be of benefit
media:
Understanding MÃ©niÃ¨reâ€™s Disease
Zero To Finals - YouTube152

questions:
A 41-year-old G3P0+2 woman presents to her general practitioner for a routine antenatal check at 14 weeks gestation. She has a past medical history of treatment-resistant schizophrenia, epilepsy, hypertension, antiphospholipid syndrome, and dyslipidemia.

Her regular medications include lamotrigine, labetalol, atorvastatin, low molecular weight heparin, and clozapine. She has recently begun a course of nitrofurantoin for a urinary tract infection.

What medication is contraindicated in this woman?
notes:
The correct answer is atorvastatin, as all statins are contraindicated in pregnancy. Although no studies have demonstrated teratogenicity of statins, there are case reports of intrauterine growth restriction and foetal demise in the first trimester in women taking statins. Lipophilic statins such as atorvastatin are able to cross the placenta, achieving similar maternal and foetal concentrations.

Clozapine is incorrect, as clozapine is not contraindicated in pregnancy. Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia that is unresponsive to first-line medications. The BNF advises clozapine should be used with caution in pregnancy, though it is not contraindicated.

Lamotrigine is incorrect, as lamotrigine is not contraindicated in pregnancy. Although many antiepileptic drugs are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenicity, lamotrigine is considered to be safe. It has not been shown to increase the risk of congenital malformations.

Low-molecular-weight-heparin is incorrect, as low-molecular-weight-heparin is not contraindicated in pregnancy. Low-molecular-weight-heparin is routinely prescribed for women with antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy and does not cross the placenta.

Nitrofurantoin is incorrect, as nitrofurantoin is only contraindicated in the third trimester. Nitrofurantoin is commonly prescribed to treat urinary tract infections in pregnancy but should be avoided in the third trimester due to the increased risk of neonatal haemolysis.
question:
A 41-year-old G3P0+2 woman presents to her general practitioner for a routine antenatal check at 14 weeks gestation. She has a past medical history of treatment-resistant schizophrenia, epilepsy, hypertension, antiphospholipid syndrome, and dyslipidemia.

Her regular medications include lamotrigine, labetalol, atorvastatin, low molecular weight heparin, and clozapine. She has recently begun a course of nitrofurantoin for a urinary tract infection.

What medication is contraindicated in this woman?

Although no studies have demonstrated teratogenicity of statins, there are case reports of intrauterine growth restriction and foetal demise in the first trimester in women taking statins. Lipophilic statins such as atorvastatin are able to cross the placenta, achieving similar maternal and foetal concentrations.

Lamotrigine is incorrect, as lamotrigine is not contraindicated in pregnancy. Although many antiepileptic drugs are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenicity, lamotrigine is considered to be safe. It has not been shown to increase the risk of congenital malformations.

Low-molecular-weight-heparin is incorrect, as low-molecular-weight-heparin is not contraindicated in pregnancy. Low-molecular-weight-heparin is routinely prescribed for women with antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy and does not cross the placenta.

Nitrofurantoin is incorrect, as nitrofurantoin is only contraindicated in the third trimester. Nitrofurantoin is commonly prescribed to treat urinary tract infections in pregnancy but should be avoided in the third trimester due to the increased risk of neonatal haemolysis.
title: Statins
body:
Statins inhibit the action of HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in hepatic cholesterol synthesis.

Adverse effects
  • myopathy: includes myalgia, myositis, rhabdomyolysis and asymptomatic raised creatine kinase. Risks factors for myopathy include advanced age, female sex, low body mass index and presence of multisystem disease such as diabetes mellitus. Myopathy is more common in lipophilic statins (simvastatin, atorvastatin) than relatively hydrophilic statins (rosuvastatin, pravastatin, fluvastatin)
  • liver impairment: the 2014 NICE guidelines recommend checking LFTs at baseline, 3 months and 12 months. Treatment should be discontinued if serum transaminase concentrations rise to and persist at 3 times the upper limit of the reference range
  • there is some evidence that statins may increase the risk of intracerebral haemorrhage in patients who've previously had a stroke. This effect is not seen in primary prevention. For this reason the Royal College of Physicians recommend avoiding statins in patients with a history of intracerebral haemorrhage

Contraindications
  • macrolides (e.g. erythromycin, clarithromycin) are an important interaction. Statins should be stopped until patients complete the course
  • pregnancy

Who should receive a statin?
  • all people with established cardiovascular disease (stroke, TIA, ischaemic heart disease, peripheral arterial disease)
  • following the 2014 update, NICE recommend anyone with a 10-year cardiovascular risk >= 10%
  • patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus should now be assessed using QRISK2 like other patients are, to determine whether they should be started on statins
  • patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus who were diagnosed more than 10 years ago OR are aged over 40 OR have established nephropathy

Statins should be taken at night as this is when the majority of cholesterol synthesis takes place. This is especially true for simvastatin which has a shorter half-life than other statins.

NICE currently recommends the following for the prevention of cardiovascular disease::
  • atorvastatin 20mg for primary prevention
    • increase the dose if non-HDL has not reduced for >= 40%
  • atorvastatin 80mg for secondary prevention

Graphic showing choice of statin.
concept: Pregnancy is a contraindication to statin therapy
links:
RCP1223
2016 Stroke guidelines


NICE1414
2014 Lipid modification guidelines


NICE2316
2022 Type 2 diabetes guidelines
media:
Drugs for hyperlipidaemia
Speed Pharmacology - YouTube91

193.concept_text: Statins inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in hepatic cholesterol synthesis

194.concept_text: Statins + erythromycin/clarithromycin  - an important and common interaction

3334.concept_text: Pregnancy is a contraindication to statin therapy

3368.concept_text: Cardiovascular disease: atorvastatin 20mg for primary prevention, 80mg for secondary prevention
